comments.commentBody:
I agree but to your list I would add Barry Goldwater. There is a possibility of a natural disaster before the election. Florida has powerplants that could be flooded before November. Think about it. Flooding, a huge surge and blackness. Flooding and huge wave surges are likely in the East Coast cities. The GOP is playing roulette with their denial of global warming.

Thanks for reading my post. I am a terrible typist and my laptop has a mind of its own.
doesn't seem very jocular to me

I can never hear the music or see the word BOLERO without remembering that incredible performance. It was perfection, and it's a delight to see it again.

Thanks, R&E.
I only watched the clip now, coming home late from a day out of town. Magnificent. I had never seen it. Thank you for  posting it!

and Elke
Don't want to UPBRAID anybody, but this was a Wednesday puzzle ?
While ALVIN, SHEL, SENECA , AESOP were in my ken, had to look up JIMMIE, WYLE and TIM.
No need to get into polemics or WAR over "polemology". It does not involve poles, neither icecaps nor Eastern Europeans.
Making JAM and PRESERVES can really TIRE one OUT , it is usually hot weather at that time . On the other hand, freezer JAM is an option.
I am not IRATE , because BOLERO reminded me of Torvill and Dean's Ice Dance routine at the 1984 Olympics. I still get the chills when I see it:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t2zbbN4OL98

Don't get EPT- does it refer maybe to NESTS?
Wonder what the rest of the week will be like. Caitlin deserves A PAT on the back .
Thanks for this perceptive comment; as Yogi Berra once said, "It Ain't Over Till It's Over"
This argument assumes that Clinton would lose the states Sanders has won.  She wouldn't.

Yes, and it's not just the NYT. CNN was showing Clinton's combined pledged-delegate + super-delegate total every few minutes yesterday evening, with little explanation, if any. It makes Bernie's situation seem dire, while it really isn't at all.

For the record, as of Wednesday March 9th, Hillary has 760 pledged delegates to Bernie's 546 pledged delegates, a substantial lead but hardly insuperable. Hers come almost entirely from states no Democrat can win in November, while Bernie's come from states Democrats must win in November. Hillary does well with demographics that always lean Democratic, while Bernie excels with independents and younger voters, who can go either way. The 461 unpledged "super delegates" -- the party establishment -- can vote for either candidate at convention time.

If Bernie can win a few more big, traditionally Democratic states -- New York and California spring to mind -- and comes into the convention with momentum... Hmmmm....

Well, I guess the Democrats, in that case, could choose self-destruction and insist on Hillary, or they could go for a Bernie-led progressive landslide that just might lead to a Democratic Congress.

Not Impossible. Could happen.

Don't you think it worth mentioning that most of the states Clinton has won are almost certain to stay red in November? And that Sanders is winning the states Dems need to win in November, and outpolling her dramatically among independents everywhere? Still think she's most "electable"?

The comment that Clinton had seemed to have locked up the Democratic race last Tuesday is laughable now, but it was also way out of line last week. The idea that superdelegates will stay with Clinton if she falls measurably behind in the popular vote is very questionable. Adding them now to her delegate total makes sense if you're trying to create a perception of inevitability for the candidate you've endorsed. Wake up, Times analysts. She's not inevitable any more than she was in 2008.

The mass media helped create Trump's momentum, and they perpetuate his
nonsense with all the free air time he gets. So they will have to do a lot in the general election to make up for that massive malpractice.

does no one see the irony of everyone saying "Trump NEVER lies! Trump never lies! he really IS the racist fascist he portrays on tv! he would NEVER lie or scam to seal a deal".

news flash:

he's lying. he's not building any wall nor rounding up 12 million immigrants.

he's doing what he always does: playing suckers. (GOP voters.)

and he's succeeding at it.

even the GOP doesn't care, as long as he's not the dead and failed status quo.

We should all be alarmed that Don Trump has swept the southern states, home of black hatred, won by a bigot focusing that culture of bigotry at new victims, the Hispanics. How else could a man from the Northeast dominate a region so opposed to the north for such a long time. Don Trump is appealing to hatred and anger. Everyone should be alarmed at the rise of Don Trump. Thank you brave Republican leaders and Congressmen who recognized this growing grave danger to our nation and the world, but it may be too late.

Either Democrat's chance of carrying Mississippi and/or South Carolina...they made a movie about that...

"Less than Zero"

Well stated. CNN, CBS, NYTimes all in the can for Hillary.
CBSN's last night coverage of the caucus repeatedly ran videos of the failure that is Rubio, while ignoring Bernie. Shameful.
And that makes me wonder how many other things they distort.  I am very disapointed  in the Times

significant upset !!!
it's just getting by, eeking by

Bernie Sanders49.8%65
Hillary Clinton48.3%68

Finally, the NYT breaking headline got it right: "Bernie Sanders won the Democratic primary in Michigan in a significant upset over Hillary Clinton".

But of course, the Times continues to spin for Clinton, noting her strong support among black voters. That is accurate, up to a point: Clinton has triumphed in the South due to strong black support, tonight in Mississippi (where she took all demographic groups) and in Louisiana over the weekend.

But the Times fails to point out that Sanders is outperforming Clinton in other regions as shown by his wins in Kansas, Nebraska, Maine and Michigan. Sanders is also making inroads among minorities. A Washington Post analysis of the Michigan results concludes that although Clinton won Michigan's black vote by 20 points, she dominated less strongly than expected. As a result, she lost the state.

The Times also fails to mention that Sanders overcame significant polling deficits to win Michigan, a sign that he is gaining momentum.

Is it possible that Clinton's deficits in the Midwest, in the North and among white voters will prove to be a weakness? Unfortunately, the Times does not even raise that possibility for its readers.

What Clinton learned (hat tip to Ms. Brazile) is that black voters in the North, especially the young, are not as obedient as black voters in the South. She's going to find herself in a world of hurt now that the southern states are mostly behind us. She also learned tonight that too many people think she'll say anything to win, and they discounted her phony flip-flop on the TPP.

What the media learned tonight is not to rely on polls or on received wisdom shilled by access journalists.
Hop: your "obedient" statement is just offensive
hop sing -- Your phrase "access journalists" captures a very large part of the problem with reporting this election. It is how the two party machines are manipulating reporting.

Close study of the county-by-county results in Michigan makes it look better for both Bernie and Trump.

Bernie was strong all over the map, and had a good 40% even in weak spots.

Hillary did well only among blacks. She did not do overwhelmingly well even with them. Her blue spots on the map are isolated in a sea of Bernie counties, and even those blue spots were only 60:40 for her.

Meanwhile Trump was strong all over the map.

Cruz did well only on the Lake Michigan coastline, our own little Bible Belt.

Kasich did well only in the university towns and in a narrow suburban strip north of Detroit that is our educated flight from Detroit proper. He was unknown elsewhere as was Cruz away from Lake Michigan.

Rubio disappeared as completely as Jeb. He's not there anywhere. Just single digits.

Bernie and Trump did not just carry Michigan, they both did well in all of the state. Their opponents had only isolated spots of support, and even that was not overwhelming.

In a very real way, both Bernie and Trump thoroughly and truly won Michigan, all of it.

I wonder how many others took this until recently banned drug - I am amazed at all the whining that she took something that was legal for so long. I think that if at this point in her carrier - if she wanted to truly game the system that she would have used a masking agent (if available) and would not continue taking something that would be detected.

Started with ORPHANED, and NATURE PRESERVES came fairly quickly, but I forgot there was supposed to be a theme until after I finished the puzzle. I was that caught up in the plethora of interesting words and clues and slightly chuffed at getting LADY MARMALADE from just LADE. Tickled by ID mail (which I didn't get until I had _OISE). Favorite was Robin Hood's target, THE RICH. [thwangggg]

Interesting perspective. The AR-15 type rifle, often dismissed in the NYT as an "assault weapon" is the most popular rifle for hunting and target shooting in the Midwest. Having one at home is about as surprising as owning a Ford truck. Bernie's less hysterical position about guns in the past may be helping gun owning democrats choose him.

It was a pleasure to read a comment so reflective of the American voter's thinking. We are, indeed, completely fed up with both Democrat and Republican establishment politics and the corporate media that only reports what both parties would like the electorate to hear. My twist on Gandi's quote for the press and the two parties alike is: First we believe you, then we suspect you and finally we ignore you. And that is the real story in this election. Better start covering it!

Republican Eligible Voter Turnout: 17.3% . . . Democrat Eligible Voter Turnout: 11.7% . . . (so far) . . . "we are all fed up" I beg to differ with your opinion! How is that a true picture of the General Election of 130+ million eligible voters? These primary results have no real meaning beyond determining the final two candidates . . . so much for an"angry electorate!!"

Holy smokes!

Hillary was supposed to win by 20 points. The Bern man won by two. Here's what I think happened.

Bernie keeps hammering about bad trade deals. The upper midwest has been decimated by offshoring. That message rings true to the voters. They have suffered terribly from factory closings.

Bernie's stand on the gun issue is a brilliant move. The upper midwest, Kansas and Missouri included, have large numbers of hunters. I have known many who like to go hunting. These people do not walk around with pistols or hoard assault weapons. They often keep their rifles locked in gun safes. Hunting is a family and community tradition. The NRA does not represent them. All they want is to be left alone. Bernie's position is viewed by them as "reasonable". That is music to their ears.

Once out of the deep south, Bernie should keep racking up wins. He could win Ohio. He could win in Missouri. Next Tuesday, I'll get to cast my ballot.

The western states should also go for him as well as the big northeast states also.

Trump will win the GOP, no question. Bernie has always polled better than Hillary against Trump.

We have ourselves a real race! This is exciting and just the thing to wake up the electorate and get people to go to the polls in Nov.

The old rules no longer apply. We are all fed up, both left and right. Anything can happen now.

I don't know how anyone can support someone who voted against TARP (and yes in the end when it mattered most, he voted with the republicans to block the funds that were needed for the auto bailout).

Love it or hate it, the lessons of the Great Depression showed us that TARP and the auto bailout were very necessary and helped to diminish the scope of the collapse which as history showed us could have been even far far worse.

Talk about a lack of judgement on the part of Sanders (who by the way did vote for regime change on a couple of occasions, even in Iraq back in the earlier days of conflicts).

Bernie, who certainly is honest about how he feels about his ideas (some of them good), is very dishonest when it comes to himself and his voting record. It is not really something to be proud of in regards to some very serious occasions.

It is quite scary to thing what would have happened had he been in charge during or right after the collapse in 2008 - another Great Depression is quite likely.
Trump, Sanders! Trump, Sanders! Trump, Sanders! The American people have spoken. Special interest groups are doomed.

I used to live in Michigan in the mid-90's. The cities are either diverse or majority African American, but some of the rural areas were very white.  There was a population of Hispanic migrant farm workers and I'm sure that has grown, but I don't what percentage are U.S. citizens over 18 and therefore eligible to vote. Michigan as a whole maybe diverse, but not necessarily the rural areas.

Did the writers read their own article? Or maybe because there were two writers they each only read and wrote half:

"But Mr. Sanders has yet to show that he can prevail in several of the populous, racially diverse swing states that the Democratic nominee will seek to win in November, while Mrs. Clinton has done so in states like Nevada and Virginia."

Last time I checked Michigan was pretty diverse. Did it turn all white between the polls on Monday and the primaries today?

We'll see how great an American he is in the general election campaign.  If he wins the primaries he has to win the general.  If he loses the primaries he has to go all in 110% with Hillary.   I'm withholding my judgement.
Cranky old white men have been running things for far too long.  Not voting for Sanders.

While I share your concern, Hillary is just not well loved.

In Michigan...feeling the Bern!
Which he didnt lose by much; just like he was competitive in Iowa, which was claimed as a flat-out victory by the Clinton campaign and its sycophants.

Hillary is in a lot more trouble than the annoyingly assertive media declarations of victory would have everyone believe. The south is not going to vote  democratic in November.  It will vote for Trump. Her victories in the south are not a sign of strength especially considering Sanders victories across every northern and midwestern state so far (except Massachusetts.)

Bernie's "revolution" cannot actually happen unless he sweeps progressives to power in at least some of those states you casually dismiss as meaningless, not to mention that he would need to align with progressives to remove many *Democratic* incumbents, too.

There's no sign of that wave happening.
now would be the time for Elizabeth Warren to come out as Bernie's VP.

Black votes, schmack votes, who cares? It's not like they can do anything for Bernie anyway.

Is that really how you see it? How depressing. I will be happy to give my vote to A DEMOCRAT. Either one.
So Hillary won in Mississippi,  Georgia,  etc.  So what?  Those states will go 80/20 Republican in November.  Things will really be up in the air after Bernie takes California.

We are used to dividing people into Democrats and Republicans, but the real division this year is between people who feel left behind by all the standard rhetoric on job creation, trade, and so on, and those who are benefiting from it. Those who are for the status quo and those who want a change.

As a Bernie Sanders supporter, I abhor Trump, but Trump's supporters are worth listening to. I mean really listening.
You know who won that battle, right?

...a tactical defeat at enormous cost and shocked North Vietnam with their massive casualty rate?
'
Well, the Sanders campaign *did* invest heavily in Michigan, without getting a substantial edge in delegates considering that there are no winner-take-all states in the Democratic primary, so perhaps there's something to that analogy.
Tet Offensive style victory for Bernie.

We don't need to do anything except support the best candidate in the primaries. Once they're over, we'll support the party, but Sanders has proven himself to be a worthy candidate and so no bandwagon yet.
Welcome to Rage Against the Machine.
duh they are democrats as well
We'll see 'bout that.

I'm not even sure it's LEGAL for Hillary and Bill to take over the White House again.

think about it:

it clearly defeats the entire point of term limits, does it not?

had they (back then) considered that famous presidents could run their now-famous wives to skirt the LAW, they would've included this in the actual Bill of Rights amendment, no question about it.

if media were honest, we'd be having this conversation.

Funny, I listen to Clinton and hear how she wants to make the lives of ordinary Americans better and how she plans to do it. I listen to Bernie and hear a guy who knows what we should do, but without any details on how to accomplish it.

Of course she wants to live in the White House. They all do. Because that's where Presidents live and they ALL want to be President. Attributing only Clinton's ambition to just "wanting to live in the White House" comes off as sexist and dismissive. She has a long history of public service.

I am sorry you missed my point.  I recognize Secretary Clinton's record and if she is the nominee I will be voting for her.  However, I do question her sincerity and I think Senator Sanders is an open book.  I have listened to his detailed plans and I support them.  Regarding "sexist" and "dismissive," though I accept it somehow sounds this way to you, neither is my feeling.  We can otherwise agree to disagree about which of these candidates best speaks our interests.

The Sanders message is sincere and directly responsive to the issues that most impact us.  That is what makes him stand apart from Mrs. Clinton.  I listen to him and am convinced he wants to right our course; I listen to her and am sure she wants to live in the White House again.
